set working environment
```{r}
require(rvest)
require(dplyr)
require(stringr)
require(tidyr)
require(dplyr)
require(ggplot2)
```
```{r}
skillsJunPan <- read.csv("C:/Users/tbao/Desktop/CUNY MSDS notes/607/Project 3/3rd version of skill.csv")
```
skillsJunPan combined Ravi's skill list and ONET Skill lists for Data Scientist, 46 skills are included
```{r}
head(skillsJunPan)
```
modify skillsJunPan dateframe fit into relational database manipulation
```{r}
#add new column with increasing numbers
# Example
skillsJunPan$generated_uid <- 1:nrow(skillsJunPan)
```
`

```{r}
# add a row counter i to make it a 
skillsJunPan <-skillsJunPan %>% mutate(i = row_number()) 
print (skillsJunPan)

```












```{r}
techskills.biostatistician <- read.csv ('C:/Users/tbao/Desktop/CUNY MSDS notes/607/Project 3/csv file of skills/technology_skills_15-2041-01.csv')
Bstat1 <- techskills.biostatistician
```

```{r}
 print (Bstat1)
```
```{r}
# to add a column called job, statitisican, with its name
Bstat1$job <- 'Biostatisticians'
Bstat1$jobcode <- '15-2041.01'
Bstat1
```
```{r}
# Use outer join, rather than inner join (close, up one more level, IT WORKED)
df_lj1<- left_join(skillsJunPan2, Bstat1, by= c('Skills'='Example')) # Example is the orignal skill name before we rename it
head(df_lj1)
tail(df_lj1)
print (df_lj1)
```

```{r}
df_lj1$jobNoNA <- 'Biostatisticians'
df_lj1$jobcodeNoNA <- '15-2041.01'
head(df_lj1)
df1<-df_lj1


# to add new column of sill indicator 1/0
df1$SkillIndicator<- 0
df1$SkillIndicator [df1$job == "Biostatisticians"] <-1
dfBStat<-df1
str(dfBStat)
print(dfBStat)
head(dfBStat)
tail(dfBStat)
```

```{r}
# before spread, to drop unnecessary columns
df_BStat <-dfBStat %>%  
  select ( jobNoNA, jobcodeNoNA, Skills, SkillIndicator) %>%
  group_by(jobNoNA) %>% 
   spread(Skills,SkillIndicator) 
```

```{r}
df_BStat
```









```{r}
techskills.Acturies <-  read.csv ('C:/Users/tbao/Desktop/CUNY MSDS notes/607/Project 3/csv file of skills/technology_skills_15-2011-00.csv')

Acur1 <- techskills.Acturies
Acur1$job <- 'Acturies'
Acur1$jobcode <- '15-2011.00'

```

```{r}
print (Acur1)
```

(skillsJunPan)



```{r}
#add new column with increasing numbers
# Example
skillsJunPan$generated_uid <- 1:nrow(skillsJunPan)
```
`

```{r}
# add a row counter i to make it a 
skillsJunPan2 <-skillsJunPan %>% mutate(i = row_number()) 
print (skillsJunPan2)

```


```{r}
# Use outer join, rather than inner join (close, up one more level, before ACUTUARIES, IT WORKED)
df_lj<- left_join(skillsJunPan2, Acur1, by= c('Skills'='Example')) # Example is the orignal skill name before we rename it
head(df_lj)
tail(df_lj)
print (df_lj)
```


```{r}
df_lj$jobNoNA <- 'Acturies'
df_lj$jobcodeNoNA <- '15-2011.00'
head(df_lj)
df<-df_lj


# to add new column of sill indicator 1/0
df$SkillIndicator<- 0
df$SkillIndicator [df$job == "Acturies"] <-1
dfAct<-df
str(dfAct)
print(dfAct)
head(dfAct)
tail(dfAct)
```

```{r}
# before spread, to drop unnecessary columns
df_Act <- dfAct %>%  
  select ( jobNoNA, jobcodeNoNA, Skills, SkillIndicator) %>%
  group_by(jobNoNA) %>% 
   spread(Skills,SkillIndicator) 
```

```{r}
df_Act
```
